title: Indian Student Killed By Stray Bullet During Shooting Incident In Canada
content:
Harsimrat Randhawa was a student at Mohawk College in Hamilton, Ontario. She was fatally struck by a stray bullet during a shooting incident involving two vehicles.

In a tragic incident, a 21-year-old Indian student was killed in Canada after she was fatally struck by a stray bullet after shots were fired by a car occupant, as she was waiting at a bus stop on her way to work.

Harsimrat Randhawa was a student at Mohawk College in Hamilton, Ontario. Her death is being investigated as a homicide that happened on Wednesday, according to the Hamilton Police, who said Randhawa was an innocent bystander.

The Consulate General of India in Toronto said in a post on X, “We are deeply saddened by the tragic death of Indian student Harsimrat Randhawa in Hamilton, Ontario."

“As per local police, she was an innocent victim, fatally struck by a stray bullet during a shooting incident involving two vehicles. A homicide investigation is currently underway. We are in close contact with her family and are extending all necessary assistance. Our thoughts and prayers are with the bereaved family during this difficult time," the official added.

According to a statement by the Hamilton Police, it received reports of a shooting near Upper James and South Bend Road streets in Hamilton at around 7:30 pm (local time). When police arrived, they found Randhawa with a gunshot wound to the chest. She was rushed to a hospital, but succumbed to her injuries.

Through video footage of the incident, investigators have determined that a passenger of a black car fired at the occupants of a white sedan. Shortly after the shooting, the vehicles left the scene.

Additionally, shots from the shooting incident also entered the rear window of a residence nearby where the occupants were watching television a few feet away. No one was injured in the home, police said.

Investigators are asking anyone with dashcam or security camera footage between 7:15 pm and 7:45 pm near the shooting area to contact authorities and provide any information that can help further the investigation.

title: Trump's White House Pushes Theory Of Covid-19 Lab Leak In China, Criticises Biden And WHO
content:
Trump's White House Pushes Theory Of Covid-19 Lab Leak In China, Criticises Biden And WHO

The website Lab Leaks mentions that the researchers of the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV) showed COVID-like symptoms in the fall of 2019.

US President Donald Trump’s White House on Friday launched a COVID-19 website that explores the origin of the pandemic, blaming it on China lab leaks. It also criticises former US President Joe Biden, US health official Anthony Fauci and the World Health Organisation.

“The Proximal Origin of SARS-CoV-2 publication — which was used repeatedly by public health officials and the media to discredit the lab leak theory — was prompted by Dr Fauci to push the preferred narrative that COVID-19 originated naturally," reads the website.

Hitting out at China, the website Lab Leaks mentions that the researchers of the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV) showed COVID-like symptoms in the fall of 2019, months before COVID-19 was discovered at the wet market.

It also says that the “virus possesses a biological characteristic that is not found in nature".

Not only this, but the website criticises the steps like social distancing, mask mandates and lockdowns.

Earlier in January, when Trump assumed office, a CIA spokesperson had said that the CIA has assessed that the COVID-19 pandemic is more likely to have emerged from a lab than from nature.

The website terms WHO’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic as “an abject failure" for caving to “pressure from the Chinese Communist Party and placing China’s political interests ahead of its international duties."

On making masks compulsory, the website notes, “There was no conclusive evidence that masks effectively protected Americans from COVID-19. Public health officials flip-flopped on the efficacy of masks without providing Americans scientific data — causing a massive uptick in public distrust."

China’s Reaction To US’ Claims

Reacting to the claims made by the website, China said that it supports and has taken part in research to find COVID-19’s origin. It also accused them of politicising the issue, adding that there was no credibility to claims that a laboratory leak likely caused the pandemic.

Washington D.C., United States of America (USA)

title: US Agrees To Recognise Russian Control Over Crimea As Part Of Ukraine Peace Deal: Report
content:
US President Donald Trump has pointed that the US might 'take a pass' on its efforts to mediate a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine.

As a part of a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine, the United States is willing to recognise Russian control over Crimea. The peace proposal calls for an immediate ceasefire between the two nations. The framework was presented to Ukrainian and European officials in Paris on Thursday.

Reportedly, the US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov also discussed on the proposal on call.

Notably, Russia invaded Crimea in 2014. The move was widely criticised by the international community, who termed it “illegal". Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy too refused to give away the region to Russia.

US President Donald Trump has indicated that the US might “take a pass" on its efforts to mediate a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine if negotiations prove to be too challenging, CNN reported.

“If, for some reason, one of the two parties makes it very difficult, we’re just going to say, ‘You’re foolish, you’re foolish. You’re horrible people,’ and we’re just going to take a pass," Trump said.

The US President is also positive about the deal. “I think we have a really good chance of getting it done. It’s coming to a head right now," he said.

Meanwhile, some details on the agreement is yet to be finalised, and the US is likely to plan more on this with Europe and Ukraine in London next week.

Trump’s remarks came days after US Secretary of State Marco Rubio, while speaking in Paris, emphasised the need to determine if it was possible to end the war or not.

“We need to determine very quickly now, and I’m talking about a matter of days, whether or not this is doable," he told reporters before departing Paris.

Location :

Washington D.C., United States of America (USA)

title: Russia says it has retaken another village in the Kursk region from Ukrainian forces
content:
Russian and North Korean soldiers have nearly deprived Kyiv of a key bargaining chip by retaking most of the region, where Ukrainian troops staged a surprise incursion last year.

By AP

Russia has pushed Ukrainian forces from one of their last remaining footholds in Russia's Kursk region, officials said Saturday.

According to Russia’s Defence Ministry, its forces took control of the village of Oleshnya, on the border with Ukraine.

No Response From Kyiv

“Units of the ‘North’ military group have liberated the village of Oleshnya in the Kursk region during active offensive operations,” the ministry said in a statement. The Associated Press was unable to immediately verify the claim, and there was no immediate response from Ukrainian officials.

According to the Russian state news agency TASS, Russia is still fighting to push Ukrainian forces out of the village of Gornal, some seven miles (11 kilometers) south of Oleshnya.

“The Russian military has yet to push the Ukrainian Armed Forces out of Gornal ... in order to completely liberate the Kursk region. Fierce fighting is underway in the settlement,” the agency reported, citing Russian security agencies.

87 Exploding Drones

Russian and North Korean soldiers have nearly deprived Kyiv of a key bargaining chip by retaking most of the region, where Ukrainian troops staged a surprise incursion last year.

In other developments, the Ukrainian Air Force reported that Russia fired 87 exploding drones and decoys in the latest wave of attacks overnight into Saturday. It said 33 of them were intercepted and another 36 were lost, likely having been electronically jammed.

Russian attacks damaged farms in the Odesa region and sparked fires in the Sumy region overnight, Ukraine’s State Emergency Service said Saturday. Fires were contained, and no casualties were reported.

Russia’s Ministry of Defence, meanwhile, said its air defence systems shot down two Ukrainian drones overnight into Saturday.

title: The 3 big mistakes investors often make — Prashant Khemka's view
content:
With decades of experience in global markets, WhiteOak Capital’s Prashant Khemka looked back on his own journey and shared some practical advice for both new and experienced investors trying to make sense of today’s unpredictable market.

By Surabhi Upadhyay

Investing in the stock market can be a great way to build wealth, but it also comes with risks. In a candid conversation about the dos and don’ts of investing, Prashant Khemka, the Founder of WhiteOak Capital Management, shared the top three mistakes investors often make—sometimes unknowingly.

These are the three common mistakes:

1. Trying to time the market:

Khemka believes that trying to predict when to enter or exit the market is the biggest mistake investors make. People often react to headlines or global events by quickly selling their stocks or staying out of the market. But this strategy rarely works.

“You'd be fortunate to get it 50% of the time right,” he said, adding that emotional decisions based on fear or speculation usually led to poor results. He’s proud to say this is one mistake he’s personally avoided throughout his career.

2. Using borrowed money to invest:

The second mistake Khemka warns against is using leverage—borrowing money to invest in the stock market. When people don’t have enough money but want to earn high returns quickly, they are tempted to take loans and buy stocks.

“That’s a mistake I’ve made,” he admitted. While it might seem like a smart move when interest rates are low and stock returns are high, Khemka says this approach can backfire badly, especially when markets fall.

Also Read: This $2 trillion global fund is 'max overweight' on India

3. Putting all your money in just one or two stocks

Khemka’s third warning is about over-concentration. He shared an example of someone who invested all their money in biotech stocks simply because they liked the sector, even though they had no expertise in it. “That’s like buying a lottery,” he said.

Khemka advises against putting too much faith in one theme or sector, no matter how promising it looks. Diversifying across different companies and industries helps reduce risk.

Khemka believes the best way to invest is to stay disciplined: don’t try to time the market, avoid borrowing to invest, and spread your money across different types of companies.

title: Bhagavad Gita, Natyashastra enter UNESCO's 'Memory of the World Register'
content:
Launched in 1992, ‘Memory of the World Register’ is a collection of manuscripts, oral traditions, audio-visual materials and archives of universal value.

By Aprameya Rao

The Shrimad Bhagavad Gita and the Natyashastra are now part of UNESCO’s ‘Memory of the World Register’, announced Culture & Tourism Minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat on Friday (April 18).

“This global honour celebrates India’s eternal wisdom & artistic genius,” he wrote on ‘X’ (formerly Twitter). Prime Minister Narendra Modi hailed their inclusion in the international register as a global recognition of India’s “timeless wisdom and rich culture.”

“The Gita and Natyashastra have nurtured civilisation, and consciousness for centuries. Their insights continue to inspire the world,” he wrote on ‘X’.

Launched in 1992, ‘Memory of the World Register’ is a collection of manuscripts, oral traditions, audio-visual materials and archives of universal value. The project aims to safeguard the documentary heritage of humanity. The Executive Board of UNESCO adds new inscriptions to the register after evaluating them by an independent international advisory committee.

‘Memory of the World Register’ 2025

The Shrimad Bhagavad Gita is a part of the Hindu epic Mahabharata. It contains 700 verses in 18 chapters and takes the form of a dialogue between Lord Krishna and Arjuna. “Due to its philosophical breadth and depth, the Gita has been read for centuries across the globe and translated into many languages,” noted UNESCO on its website.

Composed between the 2nd Century BC & 2nd Century CE, the Natyashastra preserves India’s ancient performing arts. The Natyashastra established a comprehensive set of rules that define drama, performance, aesthetic experience, emotion & music.

With the addition of the Gita and the Natyashastra, 14 Indian manuscripts are now part of the UNESCO register. The Saiva Manuscript in Pondicherry (2005), Rigveda (2007), Tarikh-e-Khandan-e-Timuriyah (2011) and Gilgit Manuscripts (2017) are some of India’s contributions to the global register.

Apart from the two Indian manuscripts, 72 inscriptions have been added to the register this year, taking the overall total to 570.

Some notable additions include Egypt’s Itḥaf Al-Mahbub, which documents the Arab world’s contributions to astronomy. The archives of British naturalist Charles Darwin, German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche & physicist Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen have been included. Moreover, two significant documents – the Geneva Conventions & the Universal Declaration of Human Rights – find a place in this year’s register.

title: Pune’s Baba Bhide Bridge to remain closed till June 6 for Metro work, check alternate routes
content:
Pune’s Baba Bhide Bridge, a crucial link across the Mutha River, will remain closed from April 20 to June 6 for the construction of a foot overbridge connecting Narayan Peth to the Deccan Gymkhana Metro station.

By CNBCTV18.com

Pune’s iconic Baba Bhide Bridge, a vital route for thousands of daily commuters, will remain closed for more than a month for Metro construction work.

Starting April 20, the bridge will remain shut for 45 days until June 6 to facilitate the building of a foot overbridge connecting the Deccan Gymkhana Metro station.

The bridge will be completely closed for bikers and vehicles as the footbridge will be constructed above the Bhide Bridge. Heavy traffic congestion could be seen following the closure of the bridge, as it was an important route for commuters.

Baba Bhide Bridge connects Sinhagad Road with Kothrud and Shivajinagar and Nagar Road to central Pune.

The Metro authorities have advised the public to use Z-Bridge, Lakdi Pool and Bal Gandharva Bridge as alternative routes to commute in the Mutha riverside areas.

During the construction period, only riverside roads will be accessible to the public because authorities will temporarily restrict access to the Bhide Bridge.

The Deccan Gymkhana-Narayan Peth area was connected through the Baba Bhide Bridge in 1996. The bridge was named after Babarao Bhide, a lawyer and social reformer.

This bridge has served as an essential pathway primarily for pedestrians, as Khadakwasla Dam releases water during the monsoon season.

The expansion of Pune Metro continues with the construction of two footbridges for pedestrian connectivity. A bridge connecting Shaniwar Peth to the Bal Gandharva Metro station has reached its final phases. The second overbridge, to be built above the Bhide Bridge, will connect Narayan Peth and Deccan Gymkhana Metro station.

According to Metro authorities, the opening of the pedestrian bridge connecting the Bal Gandharva Metro Station will reduce traffic congestion in the area.

The authorities are likely to issue traffic advisories on the Bhide Bridge closure in the coming days. Commuters have been advised to use the alternative routes till the opening of the bridge in June first week.

title: ICICI Bank Q4 Results | Net profit surges 18% to ₹12,630 crore on higher net interest income
content:
ICICI Bank Q4 Results | Net profit surges 18% to ₹12,630 crore on higher net interest income

The results came after the close of the market hours. Shares of ICICI Bank Ltd ended at ₹1,406.65, up by ₹49.90, or 3.68% on the BSE.

The country's second-largest private sector lender, ICICI Bank Ltd, on Saturday (April 19) reported an 18% year-on-year (YoY) rise in net profit at ₹12,630 crore for the fourth quarter that ended March 31, 2025.

In the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal, ICICI Bank posted a net profit of ₹10,707 crore, the bank said in a regulatory filing. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a profit of ₹11,956.4 crore for the quarter under review.

Net interest income (NII), which is the difference between the interest income a bank earns from its lending activities and the interest it pays to depositors, increased 11%, coming at ₹21,193 crore against ₹19,092.8 crore in the corresponding quarter of FY24. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a Net interest income of ₹20,853.6 crore for the quarter under review.

Asset quality

Recoveries and upgrades of NPAs, excluding write-offs and sales, were ₹ 3,817 crore in Q4-2025 compared to ₹3,392 crore in Q3-2025. The net additions to gross NPAs, excluding write-offs and sales, were ₹ 1,325 crore in Q4-2025 compared to ₹ 2,693 crore in Q3-2025.

Also Read: ICICI Bank slashes savings account interest rates by 0.25%

The bank has written off gross NPAs amounting to ₹2,118 crore in Q4-2025. There was the sale of NPAs of ₹2,786 crore in Q4-2025, which consists of ₹1,605 crore of security receipts and ₹ 314 crore (US$ 37 million) in cash. The Bank continues to hold 100% provisions against these security receipts. The provisioning coverage ratio on non-performing loans was 76.2% as of March 31, 2025.

The gross non-performing asset (GNPA) stood at 1.67% in the March quarter against 1.96% in the December quarter. Net NPA came at 0.39% against 0.42% quarter-on-quarter. In monetary terms, gross NPA stood at ₹24,166.2 crore against ₹27,745.3 crore quarter-on-quarter, whereas net NPA came at ₹5,589.4 crore against ₹5,897.8 crore quarter-on-quarter.

The board has recommended a dividend of ₹11 per share (equivalent to a dividend of $0.26 per ADS) in line with applicable guidelines. The declaration of dividends is subject to requisite approvals. The record/book closure dates will be announced in due course.

Deposit growth

Total period-end deposits increased by 14.0% year-on-year and 5.9% sequentially to ₹16,10,348 crore at March 31, 2025. Average deposits increased by 11.4% year-on-year and 1.9% sequentially to ₹14,86,635 crore in Q4-2025.

Also Read: ICICI Bank exits ICICI Merchant Services, transfers entire 19% stake to First Data in strategic realignment

Average current account deposits increased by 9.6% year-on-year and 1.4% sequentially in Q4-2025. Average savings account deposits increased by 10.1% year-on-year and 0.2% sequentially in Q4-2025. With the addition of 241 branches during Q4-2025, the Bank had a network of 6,983 branches and 16,285 ATMs & cash recycling machines as of March 31, 2025.

Capital adequacy

The bank’s total capital adequacy ratio at March 31, 2025, was 16.55%, and CET-1 ratio was 15.94% after reckoning the impact of the proposed dividend compared to the minimum regulatory requirements of 11.70% and 8.20%, respectively.

ICICI Prudential Life Insurance

The annualised premium equivalent of ICICI Life was ₹10,407 crore in FY2025 compared to ₹9,046 crore in FY2024. Value of New Business (VNB) of ICICI Life was ₹ 2,370 crore in FY2025 compared to ₹2,227 crore in FY2024. The VNB margin was 22.8% in FY2025 compared to 24.6% in FY2024. The profit after tax was ₹1,189 crore in FY2025 compared to ₹ 852 crore in FY2024 and was ₹ 386 crore in Q4-2025 compared to ₹ 174 crore in Q4-2024.

ICICI Lombard General Insurance Company

The Gross Direct Premium Income (GDPI) of ICICI General was ₹24,776 crore in FY2024 compared to ₹26,833 crore in FY2025. The combined ratio stood at 102.8% in FY2025 compared to 103.3% in FY2024. Excluding the impact of CAT losses of ₹94 crore in FY2025 and ₹ 137 crore in FY2024, the combined ratio was 102.4% and 102.5%, respectively.

The profit after tax of ICICI General grew by 30.7% to ₹2,508 crore in FY2025 compared to ₹1,919 crore (US$ 225 million) in FY2024. The profit after tax of ICICI General was ₹510 crore in Q4-2025 compared to ₹ 519 crore in Q4-2024.

title: RBI to remain 'agile & proactive' in policy action amid evolving global situation: Guv Malhotra
content:
RBI to remain 'agile & proactive' in policy action amid evolving global situation: Guv Malhotra

Observing that the Indian economy and the financial markets have demonstrated remarkable resilience, Malhotra cautioned that "they are not immune to the vagaries of an uncertain and volatile global environment."

By PTI

Amid the ongoing tariff war, Reserve Bank Governor (RBI) Sanjay Malhotra has said that the central bank will continuously monitor the rapidly evolving global situation and remain 'agile and proactive' in its policy actions.

Observing that the Indian economy and the financial markets have demonstrated remarkable resilience, Malhotra cautioned that "they are not immune to the vagaries of an uncertain and volatile global environment."

"In view of the rapidly evolving situation, especially on the global front, we are continuously monitoring and assessing the economic outlook. We will be agile and proactive in our actions on the policy front, as always," he said, while addressing the 24th FIMMDA-PDAI Annual Conference in Bali on Friday.

He said the growth-inflation balance has improved significantly, and there has been a decisive improvement in headline inflation, which is projected to remain aligned with the target of 4% in FY26. Global uncertainties and weather disturbances, however, pose risks to the inflation outlook.

Also Read: RBI Governor Malhotra warns of dwindling money market liquidity

"Even though we have projected a somewhat lower real GDP growth for FY26 at 6.5 per cent, India is still the fastest-growing economy. Yet, it is much below what we aspire to. We have reduced repo rates twice and provided sufficient liquidity," he said.

On the Indian financial markets, the Governor said all market segments, including FX, G-sec and Money Markets, have largely remained stable. While the rupee came under a bit of pressure a few months ago, it has fared better thereafter and regained some lost ground, he noted.

Equity markets experienced a significant correction, as capital outflows accelerated, a trend seen in most emerging markets. The government securities market has, however, remained rock-steady throughout the year. The gross market borrowings of the central and state governments, totalling Rs 24.7 lakh crore in FY 2024-25, sailed through smoothly, he said.

The cost of borrowing for the central government came down by 28 basis points to 6.96% in FY25, from 7.24% in FY24. The secondary market in G-secs continued to be deep and active, partly aided by India's inclusion in global bond indices, he added.

Also Read: RBI launches quarterly services and infrastructure outlook survey

In India, Malhotra said markets have evolved within a regulated framework, adapting to changing regulatory philosophies and approaches. He also emphasised that the foreign exchange markets are reasonably liquid with narrow bid-ask spreads, and there is growing transparency in this market.

In January 2020, banks were permitted to deal in FX beyond onshore market hours. While volumes are not significant, banks are transacting both prior to and post onshore market hours. Such trading, however, is largely confined to the period immediately before and after domestic FX market hours, he noted.

"Fair treatment of customers and transparency in forex pricing for the smaller and less sophisticated customers continues to engage our attention. Much more can be and needs to be done here. Divergence in pricing in FX markets for the small and large customers are far wider than what can be justified by operational considerations," he said.

The Reserve Bank has recently announced that access to FX Retail will also be provided through the Bharat Connect platform. In the first phase, a pilot to facilitate the purchase of US dollars by individuals is planned. Subsequently, its scope will be expanded based on the experience gained.

"We also continue to see banking channels being used for activities on unauthorised FX trading platforms. This calls for greater vigilance and stronger efforts by banks to create awareness among their customers about the perils of using such platforms," he said.

Also Read: RBI amasses $97 billion in gold as central banks fuel global buying spree

The Reserve Bank has been regularly updating the Alert List of unauthorised forex trading platforms and conducting awareness campaigns to educate users.

"Today, financial markets stand at the cusp of transformation between global and domestic headwinds, unprecedented opportunities and growing public expectations. When transformations such as these take place, there are many moving parts which need to come together like the pieces of a jigsaw and many stakeholders who have critical roles to play," Malhotra said.

He stressed that as India forges ahead to take its rightful place in the emerging global order, financial markets have a crucial role to play. Financial markets will need to facilitate efficient and cost-effective funding for realising the aspirations of the country, he said.

title: Ryan Gosling to lead new ‘Star Wars: Starfighter’ film set for May 2027 release
content:
The film will be a stand-alone feature set about five years after the events of Star Wars: Episode IX—The Rise of Skywalker.

By CNBCTV18.com

Ryan Gosling is set to headline Star Wars: Starfighter, a new standalone entry in the iconic franchise, directed by Deadpool & Wolverine fame Shawn Levy. Announced at the Star Wars Celebration in Tokyo, the film is slated for release in May 2027. Set five years after The Rise of Skywalker, it introduces fresh characters and explores a previously unseen timeline.

The Star Wars film franchise will have a new face! Lucasfilm has confirmed that Ryan Gosling will star in Star Wars: Starfighter.

The news came during the Star Wars Celebration event in Tokyo. At the event, both Levy and Gosling went on stage to tease the highly anticipated project.

The film will be a stand-alone feature set about five years after the events of Star Wars: Episode IX—The Rise of Skywalker. It will not follow the familiar Skywalker storyline but will rather introduce a fresh narrative and original characters.

A Variety report quoted Levy as saying that the film will not be a prequel or a sequel. It will be a new adventure set in a period the franchise has not explored yet. He promised a bold direction for the saga.

According to reports, Gosling's great affection for Star Wars was clear during the occasion, with a childhood photo of him with the Star Wars bedsheets on display. When the actor saw the photo, he realised that he had been dreaming about the franchise before seeing the film. He claimed it framed his perception of what a movie was.

He further added that the Force is mysterious, but standing on stage at the Tokyo celebration, he feels like the Force is the fans.

Jonathan Tropper, who previously worked on The Adam Project and Your Friends & Neighbours, wrote the script for the film. Tropper has been a long-time collaborator with Levy, which has generated high hopes among fans.

Lucasfilm president Kathleen Kennedy and chief creative officer Dave Filoni confirmed that the movie is looking to begin production later this year. The theatrical release is planned for May 28, 2027, the reports stated.

Gosling, coming off his Oscar-nominated turn as Ken in Barbie, enters the Star Wars franchise in what is an uncommon franchise venture for the Canadian star. A performer known for award-winning roles in La La Land and The Notebook, Gosling's arrival in the galaxy far, far away has generated great excitement.

Levy's directing credit on Deadpool & Wolverine, which earned $1.3 billion worldwide in 2024, only adds to the anticipation for Starfighter, the report added.

content:
Watch | Arvind Kejriwal, wife dance to Pushpa 2 song at daughter’s wedding; meet their son-in-law

Harshita, daughter of former Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, tied the knot with Sambhav Jain in a private ceremony at Kapurthala House, Delhi, on April 18.

By CNBCTV18.com

Former Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal’s daughter Harshita married her college friend, Sambhav Jain, in an intimate ceremony in the national capital on Friday. The marriage ceremony took place at the historic Kapurthala House in Lutyens’ Delhi.

The couple's closest friends and relatives attended the wedding. Select political leaders like Punjab Chief Minister Bhagwant Mann and former Delhi Deputy CM Manish Sisodia also attended the high-profile marriage ceremony.

According to reports, the pre-wedding festivities, including the engagement and mehndi ceremony, were held at the Shangri-La Hotel on April 17.

Arvind Kejriwal, wife Sunita’s dance goes viral

The AAP leader and his wife, Sunita, danced to the beats of the song Angaron Sa from the hit film Pushpa 2. They were performing at their daughter's engagement ceremony, which was held on Thursday. A video of their performance went viral after it was shared on social media.

In the video posted by news agency PTI, the former Delhi CM, who is dressed in a green trousseau, and his wife are seen dancing to the song starring Allu Arjun and Rashmika Mandana on the dance floor. Meanwhile, the attendees cheered the couple on.

Who is Arvind Kejriwal’s son-in-law, Sambhav Jain?

Arvind Kejriwal’s son-in-law, Sambhav Jain, is an accomplished alumnus of the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi. It was during their time at the IIT where he met Harshita. Pulkit, Harshita's younger brother, is currently studying at IIT-Delhi.

Harshita pursued Chemical Engineering at the IIT, while Sambhav, who also specialised in engineering but later entered the consultancy and start-up space.

According to reports, Sambhav is currently employed as a Project Management Consultant for a private organisation.

In recent years, he has reportedly co-founded a healthcare-focused startup, Basil Health, with Harshita. This venture is aimed at revolutionising personalised meal planning through technology. The idea was conceived from their challenges with balancing wellness with demanding professional lives.

The wedding was a private event full of beautiful celebrations. In addition to Mann and Sisodia, AAP MP Sanjay Singh attended the wedding. Singh, speaking to the media after the wedding, said that it was a happy occasion for all of them.

He also gave the couple best wishes for their marital life.

Punjab CM Bhagwant Mann was also seen performing bhangra at the engagement ceremony. Bollywood singer Mika Singh reportedly performed at the event as well.

title: Kashmir's higher reaches gets fresh snowfall, major downpour in plains
content:
This weather event has also led to authorities ordering the suspension of schools up to Class 8 in Tulail and up to Class 5 in Gurez due to the incessant snowfall and hostile weather.

By Juviraj Anchil

While most parts of India are looking for means to stay cool in the unrelenting heat, those living in the northernmost Indian state have a different story to tell.

Some areas located in the higher reaches of Kashmir received fresh snow. In addition to that, other parts of the region, including the plains of the valley, received heavy rains on Saturday.

Tulail and Gurez in the Bandipora district of north Kashmir, and Sinthan Top in south Kashmir received fresh overnight snow.

Disruption in the Valley

As a result of the moderate snowfall, the Gurez-Bandipora Road has been closed to traffic, an official told news agency PTI.

This weather event has also led to authorities ordering the suspension of schools up to Class 8 in Tulail and up to Class 5 in Gurez due to the incessant snowfall and hostile weather.

Also Read: Govt issues alert about online frauds targeting pilgrims, tourists

A few other areas in the higher reaches, including Zoji La along the Srinagar-Leh National Highway and Mughal Road, the alternate road connecting the valley with Jammu, also received fresh snow, the officials said.

Rains In Other Parts

In addition to the snow, some parts of the region also received copious amounts of rain. Widespread rain lashed affected parts of the Kashmir valley, including Srinagar.

Additionally, most parts of Kashmir also witnessed thunderstorms accompanied by strong winds.

According to officials, some areas also received hail, resulting in damage to orchard production.

The Met department said there is a possibility of light to moderate rain or snow at most places.

When it comes to the rains, some areas may receive moderate to heavy precipitation at isolated to scattered places and thunderstorms and gusty winds till Sunday evening.

The Met Office has also warned of the possibility of landslides, mudslides or shooting stones at vulnerable places.

Rains In Delhi

It is not just the valley, but the nation's capital, Delhi, that also received rains on Friday, bringing in much-needed respite from the scorching heat.

This weather activity brought the temperatures from 36° Celsius to 27° Celsius in some areas of Delhi.

title: JEE (Main) second edition: 24 candidates secure 100 NTA score; 110 cases of unfair means detected
content:
Seven toppers are from Rajasthan, three each from Telangana, Uttar Pradesh and Maharashtra; two each from Delhi, West Bengal and Gujarat; and one each from Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. Two of the toppers are women.

By PTI

Twenty-four candidates secured a perfect 100 in the engineering entrance JEE (Main), the results of which were announced by the National Testing Agency on Saturday (April 19).

Seven toppers are from Rajasthan, three each from Telangana, Uttar Pradesh and Maharashtra; two each from Delhi, West Bengal and Gujarat; and one each from Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. Two of the toppers are women.

While 21 top-scoring candidates are from the General category, the list includes one candidate each from the Scheduled Caste (SC), Scheduled Tribe (ST) and Other Backwards Classes (OBC) categories. More than 9.92 lakh candidates had appeared for the second edition of the crucial exam. In the first edition, 10.61 lakh candidates appeared.

Also Read: After UG, DU plans to implement single girl child quota in PG admissions

According to National Testing Agency (NTA) officials, NTA scores are not the same as the percentage of marks obtained, but normalised scores.

NTA scores are normalised scores across multi-session papers and are based on the relative performance of all those who appeared for the examination in one session, a senior official explained. The marks obtained are converted into a scale ranging from 100 to 0 for each session of examinees, the official added.

Based on the results of JEE (Main) Paper 1 and Paper 2, the candidates will be shortlisted to appear for JEE (Advanced), which is a one-stop exam for admission to the 23 premier Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs).

"For those candidates who appeared in both sessions of the examination, the best NTA score of both sessions has been declared," the official said. The examination was conducted in 13 languages -- Assamese, Bengali, English, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Malayalam, Marathi, Odia, Punjabi, Tamil, Telugu, and Urdu.

Also Read: Medical entrance exam NEET-UG to be conducted on May 4, announces NTA

The second edition of JEE (Main) was conducted at 531 unique examination centres in 300 cities, including 15 outside India in Manama (Bahrain), Doha City (Qatar), Sharjah, Abu Dhabi and Dubai (United Arab Emirates), Muscat (Oman), Riyadh (Saudi Arabia), Singapore, Kuwait City (Kuwait), Kuala Lumpur (Malaysia), Kathmandu (Nepal), West Java (Indonesia), Washington (US), Lagos (Nigeria) and Munich (Germany).

In the first edition, the NTA scores of 39 candidates were not declared as they were found to have indulged in unfair practices. During the second edition, 110 candidates were found to be involved in unfair means, including forgery of documents related to the examination, and consequently, their results were not declared.

"Besides these candidates, the results of 23 candidates have been withheld due to discrepancies in their photographs, biometric details or other personal information for identity verification. These candidates have been asked to provide a valid proof of their photographs duly attested by a gazetted officer to the NTA within a specified date for their results to be declared," the senior NTA official said.

title: BluSmart halts cab services: Here’s a step-by-step guide to claim wallet refund via app
content:
BluSmart halts cab services: Here’s a step-by-step guide to claim wallet refund via app

BluSmart is backed by the two Gensol Engineering promoters, who are facing investigation by SEBI for fund diversion.

By CNBCTV18.com

Electric cab services company BluSmart has suspended its operations in some cities such as Delhi NCR, Mumbai and Bengaluru, amid the controversy surrounding its founders. The development comes amid an investigation by SEBI against company co-founders, Anmol Singh Jaggi and Puneet Singh Jaggi, who are also the promoters of Gensol Engineering.

BluSmart users reported being unable to book rides for specific travel times or dates through the company’s mobile app starting from Wednesday. The company has reportedly stopped taking bookings for areas including Delhi Airport and parts of Gurugram.

Amid these developments, users who have already added funds to their BluSmart wallets may want to withdraw them. Although the app can still be downloaded, the sudden suspension of services may push users to consider alternative options for their travel needs.

Meanwhile, the electric cab-hailing firm assured its customers that it would initiate a refund of their wallet balance within 90 days.

How to withdraw money from the BluSmart wallet

Open the BluSmart app on your smartphone.

Tap the menu icon in the top-left corner and go to the Help section.

Choose ‘Blu Wallet’ from the available help topics.

Scroll down to the ‘Does this resolve your issue?’ section and tap the thumb-down icon.

This will allow you to contact BluSmart support and request a refund.

It may take 5-7 days to credit the withdrawn amount to the original source.

Gensol Engineering controversy:

BluSmart is backed by the two Gensol Engineering promoters, who have been recently barred from securities markets by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) over alleged fund diversion and violation of regulatory norms. Gensol is BluSmart’s EV leasing partner.

According to SEBI’s allegations, which first came to light earlier this week, the promoters were treating public company funds as their personal assets. The promoters are under probe for allegedly routing the funds to related entities and using them for unrelated expenses. The alleged fund misuse amounts to ₹262 crore, which was part of the loan given to Gensol for purchasing EVs. This loan was provided by the state-run Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA) and Power Finance Corporation (PFC).

As a result, SEBI has barred the founders from holding key positions in the company, casting a shadow on the company’s future.

title: Supriya Sule opposes Hindi mandate in schools, warns against undermining Marathi in NEP rollout
content:
Speaking to reporters in Pune, the Baramati MP said, "I was the first to oppose the education minister's statement about making the CBSE board compulsory in Maharashtra. What is the need to replace the existing state board with CBSE? Before discussing the language issue, we must talk about the basic education infrastructure in the state."

By PTI

NCP (SP) leader Supriya Sule on Saturday (April 19) said that undermining Marathi in the forceful implementation of the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 in Maharashtra would not be tolerated.

Sule's statement comes amid the opposition's outcry over the Maharashtra government's decision to make Hindi a mandatory third language for students of Classes 1 to 5 in Marathi and English-medium schools across the state, in a departure from the practice of studying two languages.

Speaking to reporters in Pune, the Baramati MP said, "I was the first to oppose the education minister's statement about making the CBSE board compulsory in Maharashtra. What is the need to replace the existing state board with CBSE? Before discussing the language issue, we must talk about the basic education infrastructure in the state."

Citing the Annual Status of Education Report (ASER) released by the NGO Pratham Foundation, referred to by the Centre, she stressed the need to evaluate students' performance in mathematics, science and languages.

Also Read: Hindi mandatory 3rd language for Classes 1-5 in Maharashtra; MNS slams move

She said the government should not rush into implementing the NEP, as it would adversely affect students, and teachers were not prepared for the change.

"If the implementation of the NEP in Maharashtra causes any loss to the Marathi language, it will not be tolerated. Marathi will be the priority," Sule asserted.

She said if other languages are being introduced, parents must have the option to choose. "Making anything mandatory is not appropriate. Marathi is the mother tongue of residents of the state and should remain the first language," she added.

Sule also went on to criticise the Sassoon General Hospital's report on the death of a pregnant woman who was allegedly denied admission at Deenanath Mangeshkar Hospital over non-payment of a deposit of ₹10 lakh. The report was soft on the hospital and the gynaecologist, she alleged, and said such a report "should be burnt".

Also Read: Maharashtra makes Hindi a compulsory third language for classes 1 to 5

The NCP (SP) leader further questioned the appointment of retired bureaucrat Pravin Pardeshi as the chief economic advisor to the chief minister, saying why only one advisor was appointed when there were several noted economists in Pune and Mumbai. She said Maharashtra was facing challenges in fiscal deficit and debt management, while other states were performing better.

"With regards to implementing the Jal Jeevan Mission, investment and budget management, Maharashtra does not figure in the top five or 10 states. The report released on Friday shows that the top-performing states are not governed by double-engine governments," Sule said.

"After receiving a huge mandate, a stable and progressive government was expected. Unfortunately, in the last 100 days, there has been no remarkable progress," she added.

title: Universal Epic Universe is the theme park resort's biggest bang in Florida
content:
Epic Universe is making its big splash, with single-day tickets starting at $139 for adults and increasing to $199 during peak periods, just as the Trump administration stirs up economic uncertainty.

By AP

From Harry Potter to Super Mario Bros. to Frankenstein's monster, Universal Orlando Resort is pulling out all the pop culture stops at its newest and largest theme park in Florida.

With five distinctively-themed sections and a 500-room hotel, the multibillion-dollar Universal Epic Universe is slated to open to the public on May 22, just in time for the start of summer, when the Orlando area's theme parks are usually jammed with families and young park-goers fresh out of school.

First Theme Park In Florida In 25 Years

It's the first major, traditional theme park to open in Florida since 1999, when Universal Islands of Adventure debuted, though Universal opened a themed Orlando water park, Volcano Bay, in 2017. The addition of Epic Universe brings the total number of parks at the Florida resort to four, including Universal Studios.

The opening also raises the stakes in Universal's competition with crosstown rival Walt Disney World for a greater share of Orlando's annual influx of 74 million tourists.

Universal officials also describe Epic Universe as the company's most technologically advanced theme park. For example, it uses a facial recognition system for ride express lines.

Also Read: Disney Floating Park: Here's what to expect on your next adventure

Universal's owner, Comcast NBCUniversal, also announced plans this month for its first Universal-branded theme park and resort in Europe, at a location north of London. A year-round horror entertainment experience in Las Vegas should open later this year and a family-oriented theme park is slated to open next year in a Dallas suburb.

Epic Universe is making its big bang, with single-day tickets starting at $139 for adults and increasing to $199 during peak periods, just as the Trump administration stirs up economic uncertainty.

U.S. tariff announcements threaten to limit the desire of some Americans to spend on vacations. And the rough treatment that some U.S. visitors have experienced on arrival, as well as a boycott of the United States by some Canadians, are raising fears that international tourists will stay away.

Tax receipts show Orlando's tourist economy was booming last year, with Orange County collecting a record $359 million in tourist taxes.

Here's a look at Epic Universe's different sections.

Celestial Park is the hub in the spoke-like design of Epic Universe, connecting the other “worlds.”

The astronomically-themed section is the only one with original characters not based on pre-existing intellectual property. Centered around a football field-sized water fountain and filled with abundant, colorful flowers, it's an oasis of calm between the sensory overload of the four sections.

That's not to say excitement can't be found in Celestial Park, which is home to a 133-foot (40.5-meter) high dual launching roller coaster, Stardust Racers, and an enormous carousel.

Super Nintendo World is the definition of sensory overload, from its bright primary colors that scream “Look at me!” to the loudness of the steel-drum-thumping syncopated calypso music.

It has two levels — rare for theme parks — and creates a completely immersive experience since nothing outside Super Nintendo World can be seen beyond the towering walls of Peach's Castle and Mt. Beanpole. There is an augmented reality dark ride, a kid-friendly, slow-moving omni-mover ride and a Donkey Kong-themed coaster. Character performers dressed as Mario and Luigi greet members of the crowd in a roped-off area.

Dark Universe is a throwback to Frankenstein's monster, Dracula and the Invisible Man movies that launched Universal's career in horror franchises.

Visitors enter through a recreated central European village that has a storyline about vampires inhabiting the ground underneath. There is a dark ride through Frankenstein's castle, a family-friendly coaster based on the werewolf legend and a tavern topped by a windmill with blades engulfed by flames every few minutes.

From Fantasy Beasts To Vikings

This is the third installment of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter attractions that turbocharged the Florida resort into a genuine challenger to Disney World's dominance.

The arched doorways, wrought-iron balconies and cobblestoned streets make visitors feel like they have parachuted into the Fantastic Beasts films set in 1920s Paris. The land's highlight is the Battle at the Ministry's omnidirectional lift ride, whose green-tiled, faux-gold-plated atrium is on a scale reminiscent of New York's Grand Central Terminal.

Next-generation animatronic dragons are the stars in this section, based on the “How to Train Your Dragon” franchise.

Anchored by a lagoon at its center with Viking statues, the Viking-inspired land has a coaster, a boat ride and meet-and-greets with the surprisingly agile dragons, these aren't your father's animatronics.

title: Independent Directors: 12 risk factors they should watch out for while serving on company boards
content:
The role of an independent director involves significant fiduciary responsibilities, strategic oversight, and personal exposure to both reputational and legal risks. According to Hersh Shah, Chief Executive Officer of IRM India Affiliate, in his Saturday column, independent directors should make well-informed judgments about the integrity and sustainability of an organisation’s governance framework, keeping in mind the various potential risks.

By Hersh Shah

Corporate governance failures are becoming alarmingly frequent, even in the most well-capitalised and high-profile enterprises. From the misappropriation of funds and promoter-driven conflicts of interest to deliberate financial misstatements and opaque disclosures, instances of misconduct have surfaced across the corporate spectrum — including listed entities and venture-backed start-ups.

In 2023, several well-funded emerging businesses came under regulatory and investor scrutiny for serious governance lapses, reflecting systemic weaknesses in oversight, internal controls, and board independence.

Globally, high-profile corporate collapses have reinforced the urgent need for robust checks on executive decision-making and board-level diligence. These failures don’t just undermine investor confidence and destroy value — they expose companies to legal penalties and reputational erosion, and place independent directors at significant personal and professional risk.

When governance falters, independent directors are often among the first to face scrutiny. Entrusted with fiduciary duties of care, diligence, and loyalty, they are expected to provide objective oversight and safeguard stakeholder interests. However, as regulatory frameworks evolve and stakeholder expectations rise, directors are increasingly being held liable for lapses they failed to foresee or address.

If a company’s financial statements are found to be misleading, or if material disclosures were suppressed, independent directors may be held accountable — regardless of their direct involvement. In cases involving fraud, regulatory non-compliance, or wilful negligence, directors may even face civil and criminal liability. In such a high-stakes environment, vigilance is not optional — it is imperative.

The ability to identify early warning signs and latent risk factors can empower independent directors to take corrective action, demand accountability, or, when necessary, dissociate from a company before reputational or legal exposure becomes irreversible.

Here are the Risk Factors for Independent Directors:

Below is a practical checklist of 12 distinct risk factors that independent directors should watch for while serving on a company’s board. Each represents a potential red flag that warrants close attention and prompt action.

1. Deficient Risk Culture and Tone at the Top: The organization’s risk culture – essentially how it views and manages risk – is a critical factor. The Institute of Risk Management (IRM) defines “risk culture” as the values, beliefs, knowledge and understanding about risk shared by a group (especially leadership and employees) in an organization . If there’s a disconnect between the company’s stated values and its actual practices (for example, management turning a blind eye to risk limits or ethical standards), that’s a sign of a poor risk culture that can imperil the business. Independent directors should gauge the tone at the top: Do the CEO and executives model ethical, risk-aware behavior, or do they tolerate rule-bending? A culture that condones reckless behavior or silences bad news will inevitably undermine effective governance . Moreover, a healthy risk culture requires that those at the top (promoters, the CEO, and the Chief Risk Officer) have aligned incentives – sufficient skin in the game – so that managing risk is more than just lip service. Directors must assess whether leadership truly “walks the talk” on risk management.

2. Questionable Promoter Integrity and Ethics: If a company’s promoters or founders lack integrity, even the best governance frameworks may fail. Boards should vet controlling shareholders’ backgrounds for any history of fraud or regulatory trouble. The character of those at the top is paramount – warning signs include promoters treating the business as a personal fiefdom, engaging in self-dealing transactions, or evading accountability when issues arise. Even subtle dishonesty or evasiveness from management is cause for concern. Ethical lapses at the top create a tone where minor transgressions can escalate into major frauds and put the entire board in jeopardy.

3. Related-Party Transactions and Fund Diversion: Misuse of company resources via related-party transactions is a common red flag. Independent directors should scrutinize any deals between the company and entities controlled by the promoters or their family. For instance, if the company lends money to a promoter’s private firm or buys services at inflated prices from a related entity, that warrants immediate attention. In recent fiascos, some founders treated investor capital like personal funds – leading to massive value destruction. A pattern of opaque deals that disproportionately benefit insiders is a major warning sign. Directors must dig into such arrangements and demand clear justification. Any transaction that unduly favors an insider without a valid business rationale should be blocked or investigated.

4. Financial Misreporting and Accounting Irregularities: Aggressive accounting or irregular financial reporting is an obvious red flag. Independent directors should watch for practices like revenue being recognized too early, unexplained boosts in earnings, or chronic delays in closing the books. Such tactics can mask problems only temporarily – for example, inflating revenue until the figures depart from reality . Directors should heed auditors’ warnings: repeated audit adjustments, “material weaknesses” in controls, or qualified audit opinions all signal trouble. If management cannot provide straightforward explanations for unusual accounting entries or consistently paints an overly rosy financial picture, the board should press for the truth. Reliable financial reporting is the bedrock of trust in a company.

5. Weak Internal Controls and Risk Management: Many governance failures result from an internal control environment that is weak or easily overridden. If internal audit or compliance functions are understaffed, ignored, or bypassed, issues can fester unchecked . For example, if serious problems flagged by internal auditors go unaddressed, or if there’s no independent risk officer to raise concerns, the board should be worried. Similarly, a lack of basic checks (such as proper segregation of duties in financial processes) creates opportunities for fraud. Independent directors must insist on robust internal controls and get candid reports on their effectiveness. A company that doesn’t actively enforce its controls is essentially flying blind, leaving directors exposed to nasty surprises.

6. Regulatory Non-Compliance and Legal Breaches: A company that habitually flouts laws or regulations is a ticking time bomb. Whether it’s ignoring environmental rules, violating labor laws, or breaching securities regulations, regulatory non-compliance can lead to hefty fines and sanctions — and directors may be on the hook if they fail to ensure compliance. Independent directors should watch for any pattern of legal violations or frequent regulatory penalties. Even what seem like minor infractions can signal a lax compliance culture. If warnings from regulators or internal compliance officers are shrugged off, that is a serious red flag.

7. Board Composition and Dysfunctional Dynamics: The board itself can be a source of risk if it’s not truly independent or effective. If most “independent” directors are beholden to the promoter or lack the expertise to challenge management, the board cannot properly oversee the company. In some corporate failures, outside directors were bystanders who rubber-stamped management’s actions. Warning signs include a domineering chair/CEO who controls the agenda, decisions being made outside of formal meetings, or an audit committee that never challenges reports. If the board is an echo chamber or kept in the dark, independent directors cannot fulfill their role — a dangerous situation for the director as well as the company.

8. Dominant Leadership and Management Override: A domineering CEO or founder who brooks no dissent is a major red flag. When one individual’s influence is so strong that even other executives (like the CFO) are unwilling or unable to contradict them, normal checks and balances break down. For example, a powerful CEO paired with a weak, acquiescent CFO is a recipe for uncontrolled decision-making . Signs of this dynamic include management routinely bypassing approval processes or a culture where employees are afraid to deliver bad news. Independent directors must be vigilant if they sense that all decisions funnel through one person. They should insist on governance guardrails – such as an empowered audit committee, strong internal audit, and regular executive sessions without the CEO – to prevent management override.

9. High Turnover in Key Positions or Advisors: Unusual turnover in senior ranks can signal deeper issues. If a company has churned through several CFOs or compliance heads in short order, or if its external auditor resigns unexpectedly, independent directors should ask tough questions. An auditor’s resignation is often a glaring warning – if an audit firm quits citing concerns about management’s integrity or transparency, serious trouble may be afoot . Likewise, high turnover among other gatekeeper roles (internal audit, legal, compliance) or a wave of departures of top talent suggests a toxic or unstable environment. Such patterns warrant immediate scrutiny to uncover what’s driving people away.

10. Misaligned Incentives and Excessive Risk-Taking: Compensation structures that encourage reckless behavior pose a serious risk. If executive bonuses and stock awards are tied solely to short-term metrics (like quarterly revenue or share price), managers might feel pressured to cut corners to hit those targets. A reward system that only celebrates successes and never penalizes failures can breed excessive risk-taking. Independent directors should ensure that pay plans include balanced metrics – not just growth, but also factors like compliance, safety, and long-term sustainability. If, for example, a CEO gets a huge payout despite the company facing big write-offs or compliance problems, that’s a red flag of misaligned incentives. Alternatively, if the company is witnessing unreasonably high growth, it’s an area of concern too.

11. Lack of Transparency and Poor Information Flow: A lack of open, honest information flow to the board is perilous. If management provides only rosy updates and conceals problems, the board is operating blind. Executives who discourage tough questions or deem certain topics “not for the board” are undermining oversight. Likewise, a culture of silos – where departments don’t share data – can keep directors in the dark. Independent directors should insist on unfiltered access to information, such as regular sessions with auditors without management present to hear any concerns. When transparency is lacking, issues may remain hidden until they explode into a crisis – at which point directors will be asked why they didn’t know.

12. Ignoring Whistleblowers and Early Warnings: How a company handles internal warnings speaks volumes. If credible whistleblower complaints or employee concerns are ignored (or worse, whistleblowers are punished), it signals a dangerous culture. Often, major scandals have early warnings that were disregarded. Independent directors should ensure there are safe channels for raising concerns and that allegations are properly investigated. Regulators have warned that directors who ignore red flags do so at their own peril . Thus, if a director becomes aware of a serious allegation – via a whistleblower tip, audit finding, or media report – they must push for a thorough investigation rather than sweeping it under the rug. Addressing issues promptly can stop a problem in its tracks, whereas dismissing warnings is effectively inviting disaster.

In summary, the role of an independent director entails significant fiduciary obligations, strategic oversight, and personal exposure to reputational and legal risks. By leveraging the twelve risk factors outlined above as a diagnostic checklist, independent directors can make informed judgments about the integrity and sustainability of an organisation’s governance framework.

Proactive identification of governance red flags enables timely intervention — whether by recommending corrective action, demanding greater transparency, or, if necessary, resigning from a deteriorating board environment. In an era defined by regulatory vigilance, stakeholder activism, and heightened liability, a posture of informed scepticism and constructive challenge is no longer optional — it is essential. Such diligence not only fortifies the director’s individual standing but also contributes meaningfully to preserving corporate accountability, ethical stewardship, and long-term enterprise resilience.

—The author, Hersh Shah, is Chief Executive Officer, IRM India Affiliate, the world’s leading professional certifying body for Enterprise Risk Management. The views are personal.

title: RBI Governor Malhotra warns of dwindling money market liquidity
content:
RBI Governor Malhotra warns of dwindling money market liquidity

The call money rate is an overnight interest rate at which banks and other financial institutions lend and borrow from each other. When the RBI cuts interest rates or injects liquidity, it can push down the call money rate, transmitting the central bank's policy move to the system.

By Reuters

India's call money market faces risks of dwindling liquidity, posing challenges for monetary policy transmission, the nation's central bank chief said in a speech published on Saturday.

Reserve Bank of India Governor Sanjay Malhotra expressed concern about "asymmetries which arise on occasions between different money market rates – the rate at which RBI provides liquidity, the call money rate, the market repo rate and TREPS (tri-party repo dealing system) rate".

Banks - the entities with sole access to the RBI's liquidity facilities, the call money market and the repo markets - must be proactive to ensure that the central bank's liquidity measures are "promptly and seamlessly" transmitted to the broader market, Malhotra told a conference in India on Friday that was uploaded to the RBI website on Saturday.

Also Read: YES Bank Q4 Results | Net profit spikes 63% to ₹738 crore, beats estimates on lower NPAs

The call money rate is an overnight interest rate at which banks and other financial institutions lend and borrow from each other. When the RBI cuts interest rates or injects liquidity, it can push down the call money rate, transmitting the central bank's policy move to the system.

Surplus liquidity in India has averaged 1.7 trillion rupees ($20 billion) a day this month, reversing a four-month deficit, as the RBI stepped up its liquidity infusions to support growth.

The governor also called for the deepening of India's government securities market and improving liquidity and pricing by increasing participation from various stakeholders.

There is also a need for more proactive management of risks by different stakeholders in the derivatives market, enhancing market depth, increasing the diversity of views and fostering greater competition and efficiency, he said.

title: Govt issues alert about online frauds targeting pilgrims, tourists
content:
Unsuspecting victims, upon making transactions via these portals, often realize they have been duped when no confirmation or service is received and the contact numbers become unreachable.

By PTI

The Indian Cyber Crime Coordination Centre, under the Union Ministry of Home Affairs, has alerted the public about online booking frauds, especially those targeting Char Dham pilgrims and tourists, across the country.

These frauds are being perpetrated through fake websites, deceptive social media pages, Facebook posts, and paid advertisements on search engines such as Google, the home ministry said in a statement.

The scams involve the creation of professional-looking but fake websites and social media profiles, and WhatsApp accounts offering various services.

These include helicopter bookings for Kedarnath; guest house and hotel bookings for Char Dham pilgrims; online cab or taxi reservation, holiday packages and religious tours, according to the statement.

Unsuspecting individuals, upon making payments through these portals, often realise they have been duped when no confirmation or service is received and the contact numbers become unreachable.

Also Read: 25 Indian tourists injured in Nepal accident, three critical

People are advised to exercise extreme caution, the ministry said in the statement.

"Always verify the authenticity of websites before making any payments. Verify before clicking on 'sponsored' or unknown links on Google, Facebook or WhatsApp. Cross-check bookings only through official government portals or trusted travel agencies," it added.

The ministry also urged the public to report such websites immediately on the National Cybercrime Reporting Portal at cybercrime.gov.in or call 1930 in case of any fraud.

Helicopter bookings for Kedarnath can be done via heliyatra.irctc.co.in, Somnath Trust's official website is somnath.org that can be also used for guest house bookings.

To check such scams, the Indian Cybercrime Coordination Centre (I4C) is adopting a multi-prolonged strategy.

Among the steps taken include scam signal exchange, through which scam signals are being regularly exchanged with IT intermediaries such as Google, WhatsApp, and Facebook for proactive detection.

Cybercrime hotspots are being identified and states and Union territories from where these originate are being sensitised.

Fake websites and advertisements, and impersonating social media accounts are being disabled to protect citizens.

Suspect checking and reporting features on the National Cybercrime Reporting Portal are being developed to facilitate hassle-free reporting, according to the statement.

title: Flight Alert: Mumbai airport to shut runways for 6 hours on May 8 for maintenance
content:
Both the primary and secondary runways at the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA) will be closed from 11:00 AM to 5:00 PM on May 8 for annual pre-monsoon maintenance.

By Mayuresh Ganapatye

The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA), one of India’s busiest aviation hubs, has announced a temporary suspension of flight operations on May 8, 2025, between 11:00 AM and 5:00 PM, to carry out its annual pre-monsoon runway maintenance. Both the primary and secondary runways will remain non-operational during this period.

The scheduled maintenance is a vital part of CSMIA’s larger monsoon contingency and preparedness plan, aimed at ensuring continued safety and seamless operations during the upcoming rainy season.

Recognising the importance of early communication, CSMIA issued a Notice to Airmen (NOTAM) a full six months in advance, allowing airlines and other stakeholders ample time to adjust their schedules and minimize inconvenience to passengers.

CSMIA’s airside infrastructure spans over 1,033 acres, and this annual upkeep is crucial for maintaining the health and efficiency of its operational surfaces.

As part of the maintenance routine, teams of technical experts and engineers will conduct thorough inspections to assess surface wear and tear, repair runway markings, clean drainage systems, and implement preventive measures against waterlogging—factors critical to ensuring safe landings and take-offs during the heavy monsoon rains typical in Mumbai.

To enhance the efficiency and accuracy of the operation, CSMIA will deploy advanced monitoring technologies to oversee the entire maintenance process in real-time. The airport management has also worked in close coordination with multiple stakeholders, including airline operators and regulatory authorities, to ensure the work is completed smoothly and within the scheduled six-hour window.

“This planned exercise is a part of our long-standing commitment to operational safety and infrastructure resilience. The pre-monsoon maintenance helps us stay ahead of seasonal challenges, while minimizing disruptions for passengers and airlines alike,” said a CSMIA spokesperson.

The airport has advised travellers flying in or out of Mumbai on May 8 to check with their airlines for possible changes in flight timings and to plan their journeys accordingly. CSMIA continues to set benchmarks in aviation safety and service excellence by proactively investing in infrastructure maintenance and ensuring uninterrupted operations, even in challenging weather conditions.

title: YES Bank Q4 Results | Net profit spikes 63% to ₹738 crore, beats estimates on lower NPAs
content:
YES Bank Q4 Results | Net profit spikes 63% to ₹738 crore, beats estimates on lower NPAs

The results came after the close of the market hours. On Thursday (April 17), shares of YES Bank ended at ₹18.09, up by ₹0.22, or 1.23% on the BSE.

Private sector lender YES Bank Ltd on Saturday (April 19) reported a 63.3% year-on-year (YoY) jump in net profit at ₹738.1 crore for the fourth quarter that ended March 31, 2025.

In the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal, YES Bank posted a net profit of ₹451.9 crore, the bank said in a regulatory filing. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a profit of ₹598.2 crore for the quarter under review.

Net interest income (NII), which is the difference between the interest income a bank earns from its lending activities and the interest it pays to depositors, was up 5.7%, coming at ₹2,276.3 crore against ₹2,153 crore in the corresponding quarter of FY24. The CNBC-TV18 poll had predicted a Net interest income of ₹2,182.1 crore for the quarter under review.

The gross non-performing asset (GNPA) stood at 1.6% in the March quarter against 1.6% in the December quarter. Net NPA came at 0.3% against 0.5% quarter-on-quarter.

Also Read: Yes Bank hit with ₹244 crore tax demand, to file rectification application

In monetary terms, gross NPA stood at ₹3935.6 crore against ₹3,963.47 crore quarter-on-quarter, whereas net NPA came at ₹800.1 crore against ₹1,142.62 crore quarter-on-quarter. Provisions stood at ₹318.1 crore against ₹258.7 crore quarter-on-quarter and ₹470.9 crore (YoY).

Net Interest Margin (NIM) for Q4FY25 stood at 2.5%, compared to 2.4% in Q4FY24. On a full-year basis, NIM was at 2.4%. For Q4FY25, non-interest income rose 10.9% YoY and 15% quarter-on-quarter (QoQ) to ₹1,739 crore. Operating costs for the quarter were ₹2,701 crore, down 4.2% YoY.

Priority Sector Lending Certificate (PSLC) costs fell sharply to ₹97 crore from ₹254 crore in Q4FY24. Excluding PSLC costs, operating expenses grew just 1.5% YoY for the quarter and 8.2% for the full year, compared to a 12.1% growth in total income.

Operating profit for FY25 was ₹4,254 crore, up 25.6% YoY, while Q4FY25 operating profit stood at ₹1,314 crore, marking a 45.6% YoY and 21.8% QoQ increase. Non-tax provisions for FY25 declined 42.4% YoY to ₹1,086 crore. For Q4FY25, provisions came in at ₹318 crore, down 32.5% YoY but up 23% sequentially.

The bank’s net advances rose to ₹2,46,188 crore, showing 8.1% YoY and 0.6% QoQ growth. Fresh disbursements in Q4FY25 were ₹27,734 crore, and for FY25, they stood at ₹97,899 crore. The total balance sheet expanded 4.4% YoY. The credit-deposit ratio stood at 86.5%, slightly down from 88.3% in Q3FY25.

Also Read: Jio Financial Services Q4 revenue rises 18% YoY on lending momentum; declares dividend

The CASA ratio improved to 34.3% from 30.9% a year ago. In Q4FY25, the bank opened around 2.58 lakh new retail CASA accounts, taking the FY25 total to approximately 13.15 lakh. Retail and small business deposits grew 8.3% YoY.

The NNPA plus net carrying value of Security Receipts (SRs) as a percentage of advances improved to 0.3% in Q4FY25 from 1.1% in Q4FY24. GNPA ratio remained flat at 1.6% sequentially but improved from 1.7% YoY. NNPA declined to 0.3% from 0.5% in the previous quarter and 0.6% a year ago.

Gross slippages stood at ₹1,223 crore in Q4FY25 (2% of advances), down from ₹1,348 crore in Q3FY25. Full-year gross slippages were ₹5,090 crore, compared to ₹5,334 crore in FY24. Net slippages for Q4FY25 came in at ₹696 crore, with full-year net slippages at ₹2,755 crore.

The bank's overdue book (31–90 days) declined to ₹3,705 crore from ₹3,980 crore in Q3FY25. The 31–60 days bucket rose to ₹2,194 crore, while the 61–90 days segment fell to ₹1,511 crore. title: Lady Gaga, Green Day's debut, Bernie Sanders, and more: Coachella 2025 Weekend one highlights
content:
Lady Gaga, Green Day's debut, Bernie Sanders, and more: Coachella 2025 Weekend one highlights

From Lady Gaga's career-defining performance to Green Day's debut to Bernie Sanders' surprise appearance — Here are the highlights from Coachella 2025's Weekend One, which blended music, activism, and pop culture like never before.

By Akashdeep Baruah

Coachella 2025 Weekend One delivered shock, spectacle, and star power. All at once. From ‘Mother Monster’ Lady Gaga to Punk legends Green Day, the show was an absolute testament to the love of music and musicians, along with surprise elements like guitar legend Bryan May and Senator Bernie Sanders.

The weekend blended music, activism, and pop culture like never before, raising the bar for what’s next. As Weekend Two kicks off, I look back at the top 5 moments that grabbed my attention.

Lady Gaga’s career-defining performance

Lady Gaga delivered a performance that will go down in history as the perfect mix of theatrics, talent and star power. Mother Monster transformed the main stage into a neoclassical opera house for a five-act spectacle titled The Art of Personal Chaos. Blending hits like “Bad Romance”, “Shallow” and “Poker Face” and with new tracks from her album Mayhem, she incorporated elaborate choreography, costume changes, and a collaboration with Gesaffelstein on “Killah.” The internet hailed it as one of Coachella’s best-ever shows, with clips dominating social media.

Benson ‘Freddie’ Boone and Queen tribute

Benson Boone’s Coachella debut was a high-energy spectacle where the 22-year-old pop-R&B singer channelled legend Freddie Mercury with a glam-rock aesthetic and white-and-blue lurex bodysuit. The highlight of his set was a show-stopping cover of Queen’s “Bohemian Rhapsody,” featuring a surprise appearance by Queen guitarist Brian May, who joined for the iconic guitar solo and stayed to perform “Beautiful Things” with a gospel choir.

Green Day’s grand debut amid the ‘MAGA agenda’

Punk legends Green Day made an explosive debut kicking off with “American Idiot” tweaking the lyrics from “I’m not a part of a redneck agenda” to “I’m not a part of a MAGA agenda” — a nod to their ongoing political commentary targeting Trump’s administration. From the erstwhile Bush Administration to Trump 2.0, the anthem remains as powerful as ever. Green Day set a rebellious tone, amplified by Billie Joe Armstrong’s tweak in “Jesus of Suburbia” to reference “kids from Palestine,” earning crowd cheers amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas. The performance leaned into their punk ethos, with minimal political speeches but pointed lyrical changes.

Charli XCX’s celebration with star guests

Charli XCX’s performance was a high-energy celebration of her album Brat, featuring surprise appearances by Lorde (“Girl, So Confusing”), Billie Eilish (“Guess”), and Troye Sivan (“Talk Talk”). Dubbed “Bratchella,” the set encapsulated her cultural influence, with fans and online audiences buzzing over the collaborative energy and Charli’s declaration of “Lorde Summer 2025.”

Bernie Sanders’ surprise appearance with Clairo

In an unexpected political moment, Senator Bernie Sanders introduced Clairo’s set, urging the crowd to fight for justice and combat climate change. Sanders delivered a three-minute speech urging the largely Gen Z and millennial crowd to fight for justice. He also spoke about economic, social, and racial justice, women’s reproductive rights, healthcare as a human right, and combating climate change, criticising President Donald Trump’s policies, including his claim that climate change is a “hoax.”
